docs.snippet: Now comes crunch time for the Academy Awards. The nominations were announced on Feb. 13, and everybody has had a chance to digest them, rate the competition and build a strategy. Over the next week the official ballots will go out to the 5,600 mem...
docs.lead_paragraph: Now comes crunch time for the Academy Awards. The nominations were announced on Feb. 13, and everybody has had a chance to digest them, rate the competition and build a strategy. Over the next week the official ballots will go out to the 5,600 members of the Academy of Motion Pictures Arts and Sciences. If common wisdom holds true, the bulk of them will be filled out and returned to the academy within 10 days. So if filmmakers want to maneuver or make their case, either on behalf of their own films or to discredit a competitor, they will need to do it quickly. DreamWorks is building an energetic campaign for the Ridley Scott epic ''Gladiator,'' which received a dozen nominations, the most for any film this year. This week the studio, whose ''American Beauty'' dominated the Oscars last year, announced a rerelease of ''Gladiator'' in some crucial Los Angeles theaters.
docs.abstract: At the Movies column on promotions of films nominated for Oscars; Ennio Morricone, who composed score for Malena, comments on his nomination; photo (M)

docs.snippet: Bill Clinton walked into an AIDS fund-raiser at the Apollo Theater in Harlem the other night to a flicker of applause and recognition from the audience. His wife was in Washington, so Mr. Clinton's company for his night out consisted of Representa...
docs.lead_paragraph: Bill Clinton walked into an AIDS fund-raiser at the Apollo Theater in Harlem the other night to a flicker of applause and recognition from the audience. His wife was in Washington, so Mr. Clinton's company for his night out consisted of Representative Charles B. Rangel of Harlem, the singer Roberta Flack, and a modest crew of Secret Service agents. The former president spent the next four hours in a cramped center seat, at times chatting with Mr. Rangel and Ms. Flack and occasionally autographing a program that was passed over the seats.
docs.abstract: Friends describe former Pres Bill Clinton as adrift and often isolated; say incessant controversy over series of last-minute pardons has exacerbated his forced isolation; say Hillary Clinton is torn over her husband's predicament, angered that pardons he granted have tarnished her entry into public life, but distressed that no one is around to help him deal with public relations disasters that have marked his entry into private life; Clinton's friends and advisers describe him as subdued, angered and, to some extent, perplexed at extent to which he has remained prominent and vilified figure; controversy has set back game plan his advisers laid out for him for post-White House life, which called for Clinton to retreat to quiet, dignified and lucrative private existence, giving speeches, writing his memoirs and associating himself with some sort of good works; photo (M)

headline.main: His Perks and Power Gone, Clinton Faces Storm Alone

docs.snippet: For years, the engineering company that Oscar Ocampo helped to found has benefited from a California program that pushed private utilities to increase contracts with minority-  and women-owned businesses.    Since 1986 when the company, the Ocampo...
docs.lead_paragraph: For years, the engineering company that Oscar Ocampo helped to found has benefited from a California program that pushed private utilities to increase contracts with minority- and women-owned businesses. Since 1986 when the company, the Ocampo Esta Corporation, was formed, it has grown from a company with three employees that grossed about $300,000 into one with 55 employees grossing more than $3 million last year. But with the energy crisis threatening the solvency of Pacific Gas and Electric and Southern California Edison, which account for 90 percent of its business, Ocampo Esta is also facing uncertainty.
docs.abstract: Pacific Gas and Electric and Southern California Edison have been operating under program that encourages them to buy more goods and services from businesses owned by women and minorities, but electricity crisis that has hit California has highlighted vulnerabilities of such programs; the more narrowly a company's services are tied to utilities, the harder they seem to be hit; Ocampa Esta Corp, which specializes in designing power plants and substations and gets 90 percent of its business from the two utilities, has laid off 15 engineers and designers since December, and has scaled back workweek for others; graph; photos (M)

headline.main: When California Lights Dim; Utilities' Turmoil Also Hits Program That Aids Concerns Owned by Women And Minorities

docs.snippet: AS Patrick Ewing returns to the Garden tonight with the Seattle SuperSonics, he's still surrounded by questions.    In his 15 seasons as the Knicks' center, it was always, ''If he's so great, why haven't they won a championship with him?'' But in ...
docs.lead_paragraph: AS Patrick Ewing returns to the Garden tonight with the Seattle SuperSonics, he's still surrounded by questions. In his 15 seasons as the Knicks' center, it was always, ''If he's so great, why haven't they won a championship with him?'' But in his own mind at least, Ewing finally answered that question. With an elbow to the Knicks' front office, he endorsed the longtime theory that he never had an All-Star co-star, as Michael Jordan did with Scottie Pippen when the Bulls won their six titles, as Shaquille O'Neal did with Kobe Bryant when the Lakers won last year.
docs.abstract: Dave Anderson Sports of The Times column notes that as Patrick Ewing returns to Garden with Seattle SuperSonics, he is still surrounded by questions concerning his 15 seasons as Knicks' center; photo (M)

headline.main: Sports of The Times; For Ewing, Some New Questions

docs.snippet: Ang Lee's romantic martial arts epic, ''Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon,'' packed them in again last weekend at multiplexes across the United States. Already the most successful foreign-language film in history, ''Crouching Tiger'' has grossed $81 ...
docs.lead_paragraph: Ang Lee's romantic martial arts epic, ''Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon,'' packed them in again last weekend at multiplexes across the United States. Already the most successful foreign-language film in history, ''Crouching Tiger'' has grossed $81 million and is expected to top $100 million. That is a stupefying feat for a period film set in ancient China with characters who speak in Mandarin and fly rather improbably over trees and rooftops.
docs.abstract: Ang Lee's romantic martial arts epic, Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon, is doing lackluster box office in Hong Kong, birthplace of the genre, and in China, where a dispute with distributors delayed film's release; has done spectacularly well in US and Europe and is perfroming strongly elsewhere in Asia, from Thailand and Singapore to Korea and Taiwan, Lee's birthplace; photos (M)

headline.main: Lee's 'Tiger,' Celebrated Everywhere But at Home

docs.snippet: Oscar De La Hoya, involved in a legal battle with HBO, will fight on the cable network March 24 when he returns from an eight-month layoff. An agreement to televise the fight against Arturo Gatti at the MGM Grand in Las Vegas was reached Friday be...
docs.lead_paragraph: Oscar De La Hoya, involved in a legal battle with HBO, will fight on the cable network March 24 when he returns from an eight-month layoff. An agreement to televise the fight against Arturo Gatti at the MGM Grand in Las Vegas was reached Friday between HBO and the promoter Jerry Perenchio. De La Hoya, a champion in four weight classes, last fought when he lost the World Boxing Council welterweight title on a split decision to Shane Mosley last June 17 in Los Angeles.
docs.abstract: Oscar De La Hoya, involved in legal battle with HBO, will fight on cable network March 24 against Arturo Gatti (S)

headline.main: De La Hoya's Return To Be on HBO

docs.snippet: The 651 Arts ''Black Dance: Tradition and Transformation'' festival ended on Saturday night at the BAM Harvey Theater with the inspired combination of a tribute to Katherine Dunham with a performance by Ronald K. Brown. Among Ms. Dunham's major co...
docs.lead_paragraph: The 651 Arts ''Black Dance: Tradition and Transformation'' festival ended on Saturday night at the BAM Harvey Theater with the inspired combination of a tribute to Katherine Dunham with a performance by Ronald K. Brown. Among Ms. Dunham's major contributions to American dance were her reconstructions and transformations of traditional African, Caribbean and American dance forms in theatrical programs in the 1940's. Her evident respect for and delight in those forms make it hard to believe -- as one commentator suggested in an excerpt shown from ''Free to Dance,'' a new documentary produced by the American Dance Festival -- that Ms. Dunham saw her presentations as dignifying the original dances. A half-century later Mr. Brown has imaginatively drawn on the forms in vibrant modern dance that have made him one of the most popular choreographers of his time. His new ''High Life'' blends traditional African, Latin jazz and street dance moves with modern dance in a series of stage-crosses that often look like simple struts. They are, however, a feast of complex counterpoint, patterning and sly, abrupt shifts from propulsive dance to loose walks and momentary dawdling pauses.
docs.abstract: 651 Arts Black Dance: Tradition and Transformation festival ends at BAM Harvey Theater with inspired combination of a tribute to Katherine Dunham with performance by Ronald K Brown; photo; Jennifer Dunning review (M)

headline.main: Take Tradition, Add Modernity and Make Life

docs.snippet: Russell Crowe and Colosseum carnage (''Gladiator'') play equally well at the cinema and on the sofa. But among other films, home viewers prefer to watch Julia Roberts test polluted water (''Erin Brockovich''), while people going out to the movies ...
docs.lead_paragraph: Russell Crowe and Colosseum carnage (''Gladiator'') play equally well at the cinema and on the sofa. But among other films, home viewers prefer to watch Julia Roberts test polluted water (''Erin Brockovich''), while people going out to the movies would rather see George Clooney swamped by seawater (''The Perfect Storm''). Or so say the data comparing the home-rental and box-office receipts for this year's Oscar-nominated films.
docs.abstract: How some films nominated for Oscars fare on tape and disc discussed; photo; graph (S)

headline.main: How Oscar Nominees Fare on Tape and Disc

docs.lead_paragraph: As 44 new cardinals prepared to go home after the arduous schedule of ceremonies, Masses and receptions last week, Pope John Paul II asked them to return to the Vatican in May to hash out the Roman Catholic Church's future. Cardinal Oscar Andrés Rodríguez Maradiaga, 58, archbishop of Tegucigalpa, Honduras, said on Saturday that he and his colleagues had been called to a gathering of the College of Cardinals, which, after this week, has 184 members, 135 of them young enough to be eligible to vote for a new pope. The College of Cardinals is now the largest in history.
docs.abstract: Pope John Paul II asks College of Cardinals to come to Rome in May for consistory on his latest apostolic letter and challenges facing Roman Catholic Church (M)

headline.main: Pope Calls Cardinals to Gather in May

docs.snippet: Read into it whatever you like, but travel shorthand for a fashion insider's pilgrimage goes something like this: If it's been a James Bond location, eventually the fashionable will go.    But it's easy to see why the jet-set crowd is now most com...
docs.lead_paragraph: Read into it whatever you like, but travel shorthand for a fashion insider's pilgrimage goes something like this: If it's been a James Bond location, eventually the fashionable will go. But it's easy to see why the jet-set crowd is now most comfortable in Istanbul. Drop into part of the city, and you'd swear you were in the Hollywood Hills. Drop in a mile away, and it's Portofino. Drop in a few miles more, it's Damascus. Part of it feels like Paris, part like London, part like New York, part like Cairo, part like Rome.
docs.abstract: Comment on renaissance in Turkish fashion and interior design; photos of several young arbiters; list of inspiring places to visit in Istanbul (special section, Fashions of The Times) (part 2 of 2-part section) (M)

headline.main: Ottoman Odyssey; The Empire Strikes Back
